content.rendered:
I joined a local gym a couple of weeks ago. The place where I work compensates part of the monthly membership fee. If you are interested in joining a gym, perhaps the place you work does the same.

Working out has been interesting. Usually, I go after work and stay for between 20 and 30 minutes, between three and five days a week. If I wake up early enough, I can go for a short walk but, right now, the weather is just too hot to be outdoors.

Mostly, I’m trying to work on my upper body strength, though I do work some on my leg strength. I start off with chin-ups, which I’m able to get three or four. I usually finish with some time on a treadmill.

One thing I realized right away is that it’s going to take time. Like anything that’s worth while, it takes commitment to keep working at it. It’s not one of those things that I can do a few times and see real results. Nor is it something that I can say, “well nothing has changes, so I’m just going to quit.” Real change takes time — apparently it takes a lot of time.

Real health takes time. But it’s a daily thing. It takes more than half an hour at a gym, four days a week. Tomorrow’s health is based on all of the seemingly small decisions that I’ve made over the past few years. It’s the walks and the diet and the emotional health, along with other things that help determine my health tomorrow.

What do you think? Please share your comments below.
